Clarendon Press, Oxford 1989. * [[Harjot Oberoi]], The Construction of Religious Boundaries : Culture, Identity, and Diversity in the Sikh Tradition, University Of Chicago Press 1994. * Rajendra Singh: Sikkha Itihâsa mein Râma Janmabhûmi. * Swarup, Ram: Hindu-Sikh Relationship. Voice of India, Delhi 1985. -: Whither Sikhism? Voice of India, Delhi 1991. * {{cite book|last=Talib|first=Gurbachan|authorlink=Gurbachan Singh Talib|title= [[Muslim League Attack on Sikhs and Hindus in the Punjab 1947]]|year=1950|publisher=[[Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee]]|location=India}}[http://www.bharatvani.org/books/mla/ Online 1] [https://books.google.com/books?vid=OCLC03809888&id=9fQLAAAAIAAJ&q=Muslim+League+Attack+on+Sikhs+and+Hindus+in+the+Punjab+1947&dq=Muslim+League+Attack+on+Sikhs+and+Hindus+in+the+Punjab+1947&pgis=1 Online 2] [https://web.archive.org/web/20030827045441/http://allaboutsikhs.com/books/gst/ Online 3] (A free copy of this book can be read from any 3 of the included "Online Sources" of this free "Online Book") {{Sikhism}} {{Hinduism footer small}} {{Wikiquote}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hinduism And Sikhism}} [[Category:Hinduism and other religions|Sikhism]] [[Category:Sikhism and other religions]]

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} '''Huqúqu'lláh''' ({{lang-ar|ﺣﻘﻮﻕ ﺍﻟﻠﻪ}}, "Right of God"), sometimes called the '''Law of Huqúq''' is a [[Socioeconomics|socio-economic]] and [[Spirituality|spiritual]] law of the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]], a charter document of the [[Bahá'í Faith]], written by [[Bahá'u'lláh]]. In its most basic form, it states that Bahá'ís should make a 19% voluntary payment on any wealth in excess of what is necessary to live comfortably, after the remittance of any outstanding debt. The money is then disbursed to social and economic development projects, or similar [[Philanthropy|philanthropic]] purposes.
==History==
===Gradual implementation=== :''See also: [[Bahá'í laws#Gradualism|Gradualism in Bahá'í laws]]'' and ''[[Timeline of the institution of Huqúqu'lláh]]'' Bahá'u'lláh wrote down the law of Huqúqu'lláh in the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]] in 1873, but he did not accept any payments initially. In 1878 he appointed the first trustee of the Huqúqu'lláh, who had the responsibility of receiving the ''Huqúq'' from the Bahá'ís in [[Iran]]. Later this was expanded to the Bahá'ís of the [[Middle East]]. In 1985 information about the ''Huqúq'' was distributed worldwide and in 1992 the law was made universally applicable. As the number of payments increased, deputies and representatives to receive the payments have been appointed. In 1991 the central office of Huqúqu'lláh was established at the [[Bahá'í World Centre]] in [[Haifa]], [[Israel]].<ref name="Cambridge">{{Cite book|last = Smith|first = Peter|year = 2008 |title = An Introduction to the Baha'i Faith|publisher = Cambridge University Press|place = Cambridge| pages=164}}</ref><ref name="smith">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Huqúqu'lláh |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 189–190}}</ref>
===Recipients=== During the lifetime of [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the offerings were made directly to him, and following his death, to [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]. In his [[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá|Will and Testament]], `Abdu'l-Bahá provided that Huqúqu'lláh be offered after him "through the Guardian of the Cause of God".<ref name="smith covenant">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Covenant |year= 2000 |publisher= Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 114–5}}</ref> Since the election of the [[Universal House of Justice]], it is to this institution that payments are made.<ref name="Cambridge"/><ref name="Harper">{{cite book |last = Hatcher | first= W.S. |last2= Martin | first2= J.D. |year = 1998 |title = The Bahá'í Faith: The Emerging Global Religion |publisher = Harper & Row |location = San Francisco |isbn = 0-87743-264-3 | pages = 198}}</ref>
===Trustees=== * Hájí Sháh-Muhammad Manshádi, Amínu’l-Bayán (’trustee of the Bayán’; d. 1881) * [[Hájí Amín]] (Abdu’l-Hasan Ardikání), Amín-i-Iláhi (‘trustee of God’; 1881-1928) * Hájí Ghulám-Ridá, Amín-i-Amín (‘trustee of the trustee’; 1928–38) * [[Valíyu'lláh Varqá]] (1938–55) * [[`Alí-Muhammad Varqá]] (1955-2007)<ref name="smith" />
==Timeline of the institution of Huqúqu'lláh== The following is a basic timeline of the institution of '''Huqúqu'lláh'''. * [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas|Revelation of the Kitáb-i-Aqdas]] (1873) * Amínu’l-Bayán (1878-1881) * [[Hájí Amín]], Amín-i-Iláhi (1881-1928) * Hájí Ghulám-Ridá; Amín-i-Amín (1928-1938) * [[Valíyu'lláh Varqá]] (1938-1955) * [['Alí-Muhammad Varqá]] (1955-2007) * Compilation Huqúqu'lláh (1985) * Central office of Huqúqu'lláh (1991) * Kitáb-i-Aqdas in English, Law of Huqúqu'lláh universally applicable (1992–present)
==Purpose== The Huquq'ullah is not meant to be a donation, but is rather meant to be a claim by God for support of the interests of all people. It is partly used to equalize wealth across different parts of the world.<ref name="Harper"/> The payment of the Huquq'ullah is also meant to increase the spiritual link between the religion's central institutions and the individual.<ref name="Harper" /> This offering is to be considered separate from giving to the various Bahá’í funds and takes precedence over them.<ref name="smith" /> Furthermore, the Huquq'ullah should not be solicited by anyone, and no payments of it can be accepted unless the individual was doing so "with the utmost joy".<ref>{{cite book|last=Taherzadeh|first=Adib|title=The revelation of Baha'u'llah. Vol 4 : Mazra'ih & Bahji 1877-92|year=1988|publisher=George Ronald|location=UK|isbn=9780853981442|page=253}}</ref>
==Calculation== The payment of Huqúqu'lláh is based on the calculation of the value of the individual’s possessions, which includes one’s merchandise, property and income, after all necessary expenses have been paid. If a person has possessions or wealth in excess of what is necessary equal in value to at least nineteen [[mithqal|mithqál]]s of gold<ref name="Cambridge"/><ref>{{cite book | title = Daan and Other Giving Traditions in India: The Forgotten Pot of Gold | first = Sanjay | last = Agarwal | publisher = AccountAid India | year = 2010 | isbn = 8191085402 | pages = 103}}</ref><ref name="AC">{{cite book | title = The Baha’i Faith: A Guide For The Perplexed | first = Robert H. | last = Stockman | publisher = A & C Black | year = 2012 | pages = 186–189}}</ref> (2.2246 [[Troy ounce|ounces]] or 69 [[gram]]s<ref name="AC" />) it is a spiritual obligation to pay nineteen percent of the total amount,<ref name="Cambridge"/> once only, as Huqúqu'lláh. Thereafter, whenever an individual acquires more possessions or wealth from income by the amount of at least nineteen mithqáls of gold, one is to pay nineteen percent of this increase, and so on for each further increase.<ref name="smith" />
Certain categories of possessions are exempt from the payment of the Huqúqu'lláh, such as one’s residence, necessary household furnishings, business or professional equipment and furnishings, and others.<ref name="Cambridge"/><ref name="smith" /> [[Bahá'u'lláh]] has left it to the individual to decide which items are considered necessary and which are not. Specific provisions are outlined to cover cases of financial loss, the failure of investments to yield a profit and for the payment of the Huqúqu'lláh in the event of the person’s death.
==See also== *[[Bahá'í laws]] *[[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)]]

{{Infobox song | name = Irish Son | cover = Irishsonsingle.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Brian McFadden]] | album = [[Irish Son]] | B-side = "Be True To Your Woman", "Optimystik", "Three Babies and a Man" | released = {{Start date|2004|11|22}} | format = [[CD single|CD]], [[Music download|digital download]] | recorded = 2004 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = {{Duration|m=4|s=22}} | label = [[Sony BMG]] | writer = [[Guy Chambers]], Brian McFadden | producer = Guy Chambers, [[Paul Stacey]] | prev_title = [[Real to Me (Brian McFadden song)|Real to Me]] | prev_year = 2004 | next_title = [[Almost Here (Brian McFadden and Delta Goodrem song)|Almost Here]] | next_year = 2005 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|WsW8wiWDa0A|"Irish Son"}} }} }} "'''Irish Son'''" is a [[pop music|pop]] song written by [[Guy Chambers]] and [[Brian McFadden]], and produced by Chambers and [[Paul Stacey]], for McFadden's first solo album, ''[[Irish Son]]''. {{Infobox person | name = Luis Hernando de Larramendi Ruiz | image = Luis Hernando de Larramendi.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Luis Hernando y Larramendi | birth_date = 1882 | birth_place = [[Madrid]] | death_date = 1957 | death_place = Madrid | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = lawyer | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Luis Hernando de Larramendi Ruiz''' (1882-1957) was a Spanish [[Carlist]] politician and theorist. Though his term as a party ''jefe'' was rather short (1919-1921), he stands out as monumental figure in history of the 20th-century Carlism, remaining among its leaders for some 40 years and taking part in decision-making process from the mid-1910s until the mid-1950s. As author he is recognized for his 1937 work, ''El sistema tradicional'', an orthodox lecture of [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]].
==Family and youth== [[File:Instituto de San Isidro (Madrid) 01.jpg|thumb|left|Instituto de San Isidro]] Luis’ paternal family was related to [[Old Castile]]; one of his ancestors gained recognition as member of the [[Jerónimo Merino|Cura Merino]] unit, fighting the French during the [[Peninsular War|War of Independence]]; he served under the same commander also during the [[First Carlist War]].<ref>Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi, ''Así se hizo MAPFRE. Mi tiempo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863875}}, pp. 35-36</ref> Later on the family found itself on the descendant path and Luis’ grandparents were referred to as "laboradores modestos".<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 35</ref> His father, [[Mariano Hernando Ruiz]] (1861-1913),<ref>''La Corresppondencia de España'' 30.11.13, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000673540&page=6 here]</ref> originated from [[Riaza]] in the [[province of Segovia]]; he studied medicine but upon graduating has never practiced;<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 27</ref> instead, he made a living by trading arts, mostly paintings and sculptures.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 36; he tried his hand also in photography, see ''Industria y Invenciones'' 16.12.89, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001478655&page=9 here]</ref> Heavily engaged in preparing the Spanish pavilion for the [[Exposition Universelle (1889)|Paris Exposition Universelle of 1889]], apart from presenting art<ref>''L’Espagne. Exposition historique de Madrid'', Paris 1894, p. 307, available [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5652130x/f318.image.r here]</ref> he also co-ordinated works related to construction of a bullring in the [[Jardins du Trocadéro|Trocadero park]].<ref>''Le Figaro'' 03.07.89, available [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k280814n/f3.item.r here]</ref> He has never made it to the affluent bourgeoisie strata and back in [[Madrid]] suffered financial problems,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 28</ref> living first at Calle Ancha de San Bernardo and then at Calle Lista.<ref>now named Calle Ortega y Gasset</ref> Mariano Hernando married Maria Cuadrado, with whom he had 3 children. Upon her premature death he remarried with Luisa Larramendi Serrano, also a madrileña though of [[Álava|Alavese]] origins.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 36</ref> The couple had 6 children, Luis born as the oldest of the siblings and the only son.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 37</ref>
The young Luis was first educated at the Madrid [[Instituto San Isidro|Instituto de San Isídro]], a prestigious [[Jesuit]] establishment with long distinguished record; it is there where he got his [[Baccalaureate (Spain)|baccalaureate]] and where he made acquaintances, some of them later public figures like Luis Urquijo, marqués de Amurrio.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 28</ref> However, it is also at the college where despite his penchant for letters he ran into problems with the teacher of Retórica y Poética, resulting in Luis’ later lukewarm attitude towards the Jesuits and formal education.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 28-29</ref> At unspecified date he entered Facultad de Derecho at [[Complutense University of Madrid|Universidad de Madrid]];<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 28</ref> not averse towards bohemian lifestyle, he befriended the likes of [[Alejandro Sawa]] and [[Ramón Valle-Inclán|Ramón Valle Inclán]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 27-28</ref> Date of graduation is not known, apart that it was prior to 1905; at that time he was already practicing law as an intern,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 46</ref> to open his own law office later on. In honor of his maternal family Luis got his name changed from Hernando y Larramendi to Hernando de Larramendi y Ruiz.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 35</ref> [[File:Calle de Velázquez (Madrid) 01.jpg|thumb|Calle Velázquez, Madrid]] During his academic years Larramendi met a sister of his university colleague Mariano de Montiano,<ref>Mariano has later set up a bookstore in Bilbao, named Libreria Montiano, Larramendi 2000, p. 39</ref> María de Montiano y Uriarte (1886-1976),<ref>see ''Montiano'' entry, [in:] ''Euskalnet'' service, available [http://www.euskalnet.net/laviana/gen_bascas/montianocompleto.html here]</ref> originating from [[Bilbao]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 28</ref> Daughter of a physician,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 37</ref> descendant to a noble prestigious family<ref>the Montiano family originated from Villasana del Mena and was noted in history of Bilbao already in the 16th century; its representatives held most prestigious positions in the 18th century, the best known of them general and governor of Florida, Manuel de Montiano y Sopelana</ref> and considered the most handsome girl in the city,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 37</ref> she was also fanatically [[Basque people|Basque]].<ref>in pre-Nationalist Sabiñan terms, in her case also strongly flavored with racism; she could list 240 names of her Basque ancestors, Larramendi 2000, p. 37</ref> They married at unspecified time, though prior to 1904;<ref>their first child was born 1904, ''ABC'' 27.05.07, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2007/05/27/078.html here]</ref> he tended to be quiet and unassuming, she was also introvert, but of a decisive and bold character.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 27</ref> The couple settled at Calle Valázquez;<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 38</ref> they had 9 children, 6 boys and 3 girls.<ref>see ''Montiano'' entry, [in:] ''Euskalnet'' service, available [http://www.euskalnet.net/laviana/gen_bascas/montianocompleto.html here]</ref> The oldest son, [[Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi y Montiano|Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi]], became known nationwide as longtime manager and the moving spirit behind [[MAPFRE]], a corporate insurance giant; other children did not grow to prominence nationwide.<ref>one son became a Ministry of Justice official, another settled as a physician in Chicago and another was a publisher, Larramendi 2000, p. 40</ref> Luis' grandson, Luis Hernando de Larramendi y Martínez, is one of the current Carlist leaders.<ref>see e.g. Juan Beltrán, ''Larramendi carlista de raza'', [in:] ''La Razón'' 20.11.11, available [http://www.larazon.es/historico/4894-larramendi-carlista-de-raza-HLLA_RAZON_412864#.Ttt1AKnHmLUd6bQ here]</ref>
==Early public career (prior to 1912)== [[File:Don carlos de borbón nypl.jpg|left|thumb|160px|Don Carlos, Carlist king 1868-1909]] Mariano Hernando was not a Carlist;<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 35</ref> it was thanks to the influence of his paternal grandfather that during his childhood and youth Luis embraced Carlism.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 46</ref> When at the University he befriended a number of Traditionalist-minded students like [[Tomás Domínguez Arévalo|conde Rodezno]], [[José Pascual de Liñán y Eguizábal|conde de Doña Marina]]<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 28</ref> and [[:es:Rafael Díaz Aguado y Salaberry|Rafael Díaz Aguado Salaberry]];<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 29</ref> together with them in the first decade of the 20th century he was active in Juventud Carlista and Congregación de los Luises, a Jesuit youth organization.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 47</ref> In 1904 he was briefly editor-in-chief of an ephemeral Carlist daily ''El Correo de Guipúzcoa'', though it is not clear whether he lived in [[San Sebastián]] at that time.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 31, 46</ref> In Madrid he gained recognition in 1905 becoming secretary of Sección de Ciencias Historicas of [[Ateneo de Madrid]],<ref>''Diario Oficial'' 06.06.05, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000705124&page=3 here]</ref> though principally as a young and successful lawyer, involved in cases gaining wider publicity.<ref>when working as an intern in the office of prestigious Republican lawyer Toledano, Larramendi defended Aquilino Martínez Herrero, involved in Mateo Morral’s bombing attempt during the wedding of Alfonso XIII. He went to great lengths and possibly even not quite according to the rules, as was reprimended by the Tribunal, but managed to get his client acquitted. The case earned him prestige and respect among the Anarchists, Larramendi 2000, p. 29</ref>
When in Ateneo Larramendi embarked on Catholic propaganda, trying to confront the growing secularization tide. In 1906 he addressed [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] with legal note, aimed against the plan to introduce civil marriages;<ref>the brochure was personally aimed against the then minister of justice, conde de Romanones, and was titled ''Romanones a la barra!''; the campaign was co-ordinated with the bishops, Larramendi 2000, p. 47</ref> in 1910 he published ''Cómo defendernos de las escuelas laicas'', a booklet aimed against the concept of public, secular, free and obligatory school, launched by the republican groupings; Larramendi claimed that fathers had the right to bring up their children the way they wanted.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 47</ref> Campaigning against secular education carried him as far as to [[Andalusia]],<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.06.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000289855&page=1 here]</ref> though his principal battleground were various public fora of the capital; apart from the Ateneo<ref>''La Epoca'' 08.12.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000813758&page=4 here]</ref> he spoke also in theatres<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 27.04.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000304612&page=1 here]</ref> and apart from education discussed also Catholic syndicalism<ref>''El Imparcial'' 09.12.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000287470&page=3 here]</ref> and episodes of public blasphemy,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 27.04.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000304612&page=1 here]</ref> soon growing to president of the Madrid branch of Juventud Jaimista.<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 26.05.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000648830&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Jaimist meeting Vitoria 1911.JPG|thumb|Carlist meeting, 1911]] [[Spanish general election, 1910|In 1910]] Larramendi decided to run on Traditionalist ticket for the Cortes; as he was unrelated to [[Asturias]], it is not clear why he chose the district of [[Oviedo (province)|Oviedo]]. Competing against local heavyweights like [[Melquíades Álvarez (politician)|Melquíades Álvarez]] and [[:es:José Manuel Pedregal|José Manuel Pedregal]] he stood little chance and lost,<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 10.05.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000615707&page=1 here]</ref> afterwards appealing corruption and unfair deployment of [[Guardia Civil]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 48</ref> The following year he tried his chances in local elections in [[Valencia]]; this time banking on support of local Carlists like [[:es:Manuel Simó Marín|Manuel Simó]] and [[:es:Luis Lucia Lucia|Luis Lucia]], the latter running a daily ''Diario de Valencia''; the bid proved unsuccessful.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 47-48</ref> In Madrid he engaged in launching a periodical of Traditionalist youth, which eventually materialized as ''Juventud – Organo de las Juventudes Tradicionalistas''. Given lack of broader Carlist base in Madrid the initiative proved to be short-lived, and the weekly was issued in 1912-1913 only. Nevertheless, Larramendi was already well known among conservative youth of the capital: "quién no conoce al simpático y cultisimo Larramendi?" – asked one of the periodicals.<ref>"Quién no ha leído sus originalísimos artículos, y saboreado sus libros singulares, y aplaudido entusiasmado su mágica palabra? Joven de preclaro entendimento, agudísimo ingenio, imaginación despierta y erudición vastisima", quoted after Larramendi 2000, p. 48</ref> With ease of writing, by the mid-1910s he supplied Carlist periodicals as far as [[Tortosa]],<ref>''La Tradicion'', José Navarro Cabanes, Apuntes bibliográficos de la prensa carlista, Valencia 1917, p. 259</ref> [[Castellón de la Plana|Castellón]],<ref>''El Maestrazgo'', Navarro Cabanes 1917, p. 269</ref> [[Alicante]]<ref>''El Cañon'', Navarro Cabanes 1917, p. 294</ref> and [[Badajoz]],<ref>''Pueblo Extremeño'', Navarro Cabanes 1917, p. 304</ref> let alone other titles in Madrid.<ref>''El Combate'', Navarro Cabanes 1917, p. 276</ref>
==Rising star (1912-1919)== [[File:ULL.48.75.1.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Larramendi speaking, 1912]] In the 1910s Larramendi neared the socially-minded Carlists known as the "Zaragoza group" and composed of [[Pascual Comín]], [[Salvador Minguijón Adrián|Salvador Minguijón]], [[:es:Severino Azna|Severino Azna]]r and [[Inocencio Jiménez]]; they animated ''La Paz Social'' periodical and the likewise named booklet series that the first Larramendi’s work formed part of.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 50</ref> He co-operated with their Centro de Publicaciones Católicas, fascinated by French Catholic scholars grouped around [[Leon Garriguet]]. Though he eventually failed to translate [[Antonin Sertillanges]],<ref>to be titled ''Feminismo y Cristianismo'', Larramendi 2000, p. 50</ref> thanks to his work the Centro released the Spanish version of [[Albert Rougenant|Albert Rougenant’s]] ''A propos de la crise de l'Apprentissage'' (1911).<ref>in the Spanish version titled ''Patrones y obreros'', Nuestro Tiempo 1911, p. 142, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002544735&page=142 here]</ref>
Also in liaison with the [[Zaragoza]] group Larramendi published a series of booklets under the common title ''En la Avanzada''.<ref>see ''Sancho el Sabio'' catalogue, available [http://catalogo.fsancho-sabio.es/Record/3894/TOC here]</ref> ''Crítica política. Cuestiones vascas. Cinematógrafo'' (1911) exploited the revolution v. counterrevolution antinomy; touching upon the Basque subject, it defended provincial fueros but lambasted separatists. ''Catecismo á los ateos. ¿Qué son las escuelas laicas? Romanones, ¡á la barra!'' (1913) re-prnted earlier pamphlets and went on with new onslaught on secular education, based on outdated illusions of [[Rousseau]]. Finally, ''¡Viva el Rey! Psicología social y literaria'' (1914) tackled major issues like monarchy, strikes, self-government and labor organization, though it also discussed literature.<ref>e.g. he presented Valle-Inclan, Marquina or Gabriel y Galán as proto-Traditionalists, Larramendi 2000, p. 49</ref> Apart from publications he did not neglect attending public meetings, delivering addresses across Spain at gatherings flavored with Carlism or social-Catholicism.<ref>e.g. in Ciudad Real - José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer católicismo social español'' [PhD thesis UNED], Madrid 2012, pp. 78, 95, La Coruña - Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 95, 105, Valladolid - Orella Martínez 2012, p. 157, Zamora - Orella Martínez 2012, p. 166</ref>
In the 1910s Carlism was increasingly paralyzed by internal crisis related to conflict between the claimant [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]] and the key party theorist, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]]; both factions competed to control the Madrid-based semi-official Carlist daily, ''[[:es:El Correo Español|El Correo Español]]''.<ref>for details, see Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, pp. 465-472</ref> Larramendi remained fully loyal to his king; moreover, as a lawyer he helped to transfer the newspaper ownership to marqués de Valldespina and to purge the editorial board from dissenters like [[:es:Miguel Fernández Peñaflor|Peñaflor]].<ref>Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 71</ref> He confirmed his image of a loyal subject also during the [[Spanish general election, 1914|1914 elections]]. With propaganda campaign already in full swing, the party candidate in [[Vitoria-Gasteiz|Vitoria]], [[Esteban de Bilbao Eguía|Esteban Bilbao]], balked at the official plan and fielded his candidature in [[Durango, Biscay|Durango]]; as emergency measure Larramendi was asked to replace him. It turned out he had little chance standing against the Conservative leader, [[Eduardo Dato]], though following defeat he did not hesitate to appeal administrative pressure.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 50-51</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] In the late 1910s Larramendi was already recognized as an important figure in the party,<ref>"una figura muy destacada dentro del Partido", Larramendi 2000, p. 51</ref> though he did not rise to executive structures either nationwide or on the regional Castilian basis<ref>the regional jefe for Castilla La Nueva was Celestino de Alcocer, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 443</ref> and was rather considered a young man for the future.<ref>[[Melchor Ferrer Dalmau|Melchor Ferrer]], ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. XXIX, Sevilla 1960, p. 121</ref> The setting changed dramatically when following the end of [[World War One]] the claimant was released from his confinement in [[Austria]] and early 1919 arrived in [[Paris]] to reclaim party leadership from the [[Mellismo|Mellistas]]. The conflict exploded in expulsion of de Mella and massive defections of his supporters, many of them occupying key positions in Carlist structures; command chain of the party was decimated. Political delegate of the king in Spain, [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marqués de Cerralbo]], resigned; he was only provisionally replaced by Pascual Comín, who upon appointment declared he was not prepared to stay at the helm longer than provisionally.<ref>Ferrer 1960, pp. 119-120</ref>
==Leader (1919-1921)== [[File:ULL.19.18.18.jpg|thumb|left|Larramendi and [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], 1919]] Comín appreciated Larramendi following works of the Zaragoza group; he suggested that the Madrid lawyer becomes his replacement.<ref>Ferrer 1960, pp 119-121</ref> Don Jaime acknowledged Larramendi’s loyalty during the strife for control of ''El Correo''. Moreover, as a young militant deprived of own political basis<ref>Larramendi had no intimate political friends and tended to be a lone player, Ferrer 1960, p. 123</ref> he seemed to have posed no threat to royal leadership; his location in Madrid and profession of a lawyer offered additional advantages. Lack of experience was a disadvantage; [[Francisco Martín Melgar y Rodríguez|Melgar]] dissuaded the choice also due to pro-German Larramendi’s leaning during the war.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 146, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 515; Larremendi remained a German sympathiser also later on, José Javier López Antón, ''Trayectoria ideológica del carlismo bajo don Jaime III, 1909-1931'', [in:] ''Aportes'' 15 (1990), p. 40</ref> Don Jaime’s special envoy<ref>named Miguel de Torres</ref> to Madrid returned with good news and in August 1919 the claimant appointed Larramendi his key representative in Spain and effectively the party leader, though not with the title of Jefe Delegado, but as a Secretario General.<ref>Ferrer 1960, pp. 119-120, Larramendi 2000, p. 52</ref>
Larramendi faced an extremely difficult task of re-building command structures.<ref>perhaps Larramendi’s best known personal decision is appointing Juan Perez de Najera as replacement of Joaquín Llorens at the helm of Carlist requeté militia, Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo. Dos siglos de contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788420639475}}, p. 277. The decision was rather an unfortunate one, as the 75-year-old did little to reinvigorate the ailing organisation</ref> He threw himself into a series of hectic meetings with provincial and regional leaders, incessantly touring the country;<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 515, Canal 2000, p. 277</ref> in some cases, like [[Catalonia]] or [[Valencia Region|Valencia]], he faced also bitter personal conflicts.<ref>Ferrer 1960, p. 124</ref> Apart from that, as a lawyer he successfully kept fighting off the Mellistas when struggling for ''El Correo''.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 51. He released also an anti-Mellist booklet, ''Omisiones y Desvaríos de Mella'', published in 1919, Larramendi 2000, p. 49</ref> His first major initiative was launching the project of a grand Carlist assembly; it materialized in November 1919 as Magna Junta de [[Biarritz]].<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 184, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 516, Ferrer 1960, p. 124, Canal 2000, p. 277</ref> The event was a success as it consolidated the party and helped it to re-gain momentum, even though in none of 3 major issued debated - re-organization, financial problems and marriage of Don Jaime - any key decision was adopted.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 277</ref>
In 1920 Larramendi focused mostly on engineering the Carlist electoral campaign; none of the scholarly sources consulted provides information on what strategy he adopted, though he is known to have angrily rejected veiled calls for a low-denomination Catholic right-wing alliance, advocated by emergent accidentalist [[Christian democracy|Christian-Democratic]] groupings and their mouthpiece, ''[[El Debate]]''.<ref>"a no ser que sea tradicionalista el derecho que no es católico ni protestante; y que ‘futuras Constituciones’ vistas a través de la rusa bolchevique y de la alemana socialista, sean tradicionalistas también; y que la ‘dictadura’, sea tradicionalismo; y que lo sea la ‘representación proporcional’; y la ‘expropiación de la tierra; y hasta Galdós..", quoted after Andrés Martín 2000, p. 189</ref> The campaign was an utter failure; 3 mandates secured<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 520; the Carlists gained also 2 seats in the senate, Melchor Ferrer, ''Breve historia del legitimismo español'', Madrid 1958, p. 102</ref> was the worst result since the [[Electoral Carlism (Restoration)|Carlists joined electoral competition]] in the early 1890s. Also personally Larramendi had to acknowledge defeat: running in the [[Navarre]]se district of [[Aoiz]], for some 20 years almost an exclusive Carlist electoral fiefdom, he lost to a [[Conservative Party (Spain)|Conservative]] counter-candidate.<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 13.12.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000770100&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Junta de Biarritz.jpg|thumb|Junta de Biarritz]] In 1921 Larramendi seemed already overwhelmed by mounting problems;<ref>he found time to cultivate his penchant for letters and issued to satirical publications, a short drama ''Papá Ministro'' and ''Guía Sociológica de Aspirantes al Matrimonió'', Larramendi 2000, p. 52, Ferrer 1960, p. 122</ref> another one were rumors about negotiations related to some sort of dynastic accord, allegedly conducted by Don Jaime with the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsist branch]]; Larramendi has always been fiercely hostile to any compromise with the despised Liberal dynasty. He arranged for another grand meeting; it took place in [[Lourdes]], though due to lower attendance and minor scale of discussions taking place it was rather an operational session than a milestone comparable to the Biarritz amassment;<ref>Ferrer 1960, p. 142</ref> it provided Larramendi with little assistance. Soon afterwards the claimant left for [[Colombia]] with hardly any guidance or information passed to his delegate in Spain; upon his return, in the summer of 1921, Larramendi handed his resignation.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 52, Ferrer 1960, p. 117</ref> When discussing its background, some scholars claim he was tired of uphill struggle;<ref>Ferrer 1960, p. 147</ref> others point to talks with the Alfonsists and general Don Jaime’s detachment<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 52, Ferrer 1960, p. 117</ref> or Larramendi’s remorse about the 1920 electoral disaster.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 278</ref>
==In the back seat (1921-1930)== [[File:Marqués de Villores 2.png|thumb|160px|left|Marqués de Villores]] Replaced as Carlist political leader by [[José Selva Mergelina|marqués de Villores]], Larramendi remained engaged in the party executive; his activity was related to dynastical issues rather than to daily business. In 1922 he represented Don Jaime’s sister, [[Infanta Blanca of Spain|Doña Blanca]], in court; wife to a member of the imperial [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg house]] she refused to recognize the [[First Austrian Republic|Austrian republic]] and sought shelter in Spain. Larramendi presented her case when claiming the Spanish citizenship, resulting in a booklet titled ''Dictamen referente a la nacionalidad de S.A.R. Doña Blanca de Borbón y Borbón''.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 53, the booklet is available at Fundación de Larramendi site, see [http://www.larramendi.es/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina&path=1001247 here]</ref> His efforts were crowned with success and Doña Blanca with her family settled in [[Barcelona]]. In the future the episode would prove of great value for the [[Carloctavismo|Carloctavista]] dynastic claim,<ref>for detailed discussion, see José Maria de Montells y Galán, ''La Otra Dinastia, 1833-1975'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|8492001658}}, Francisco de las Heras y Borrero, ''Un pretendiente desconocido. Carlos de Habsburgo. El otro candidato de Franco'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|8497725565}}, César Alcalá, ''Cruzadistas y carloctavistas: historia de una conspiración'', Barcelona 2012, {{ISBN|9788493884253}}</ref> but no source clarifies whether in the early 1920s Larramendi considered her sons would-be claimants to the Spanish throne. It is confirmed, however, that he was acutely aware of the looming dynastical crisis.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 53</ref> As Don Jaime, at that time in his early 50s, had no offspring, the Carlist branch was endangered with extinction. Larramendi kept advocating last-minute rescue mission by Don Jaime’s marriage with his niece;<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 53, Ferrer 1960, p. 140</ref> the scheme crashed when in 1922 Fabiola Massimo married an Italian aristocrat.<ref>see ''Fabiola Massimo'' entry at ''The Peerage'' service, available [http://www.thepeerage.com/p8649.htm#i86489 here]</ref> [[File:Jaime de Borbón, in El Mundo Grafico 7 10 1931 página 24.jpg|thumb|160px|Don Jaime, Carlist king 1909-1931]] The 1923 advent of [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship brought national political life to a standstill: all parties have been dissolved. It seems that initially Larramendi welcomed the coup as doing away with a long overdue liberal democracy and a stepping stone towards Traditionalist monarchy, position fairly popular among the Carlists; his friend, [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Víctor Pradera]],<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 31</ref> wholeheartedly engaged in building the regime structures. In late 1924 Larramendi addressed the military directorate with a letter; it contained congratulations on "patriotic work" and offered personal services.<ref>''Heraldo Alaves'' 04.12.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=4&path=1000026415&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Another letter denied lack of understanding for "movimiento regenerador de 13 de Septiembre"; written from clearly Jaimist positions, it praised the military for cracking down on [[:es:Caciquismo (España)|caciquismo]] and bureaucracy, considered support for the government "most basic duty of a citizen" and even declared [[Alfonso XIII of Spain|Alfonso XIII]] "más fecunda encarnación de España".<ref>''Diario de Valencia'' 12.12.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000192713&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
It seems that in the mid-1920s Larramendi’s lukewarm approval turned into disappointment, still in line with official line adopted by Don Jaime. He could not understand how Rodezno, his juvenile acquaintance of love-and-hate relationship, could have accepted the [[Villafranca]] mayorship "given the circumstances";<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 30</ref> by his son he was recollected as opposed to Primo and refusing to join either [[Patriotic Union (Spain)|Unión Patriótica]] or any other primoderiverista structure.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 31, 53-4</ref> Indeed, in the late 1920s he was recorded mostly as active in the Catholic realm, giving lectures<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.03.28, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000440340&page=3 here], also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 04.02.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000481873&page=6 here]</ref> and once assigned a somewhat ambiguous praise of "[[Ángel Ganivet|Ganivet]] Católico".<ref>''Oro de Ley'' 15.01.26, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004509711&page=18 here]</ref> Though in 1930 he took part in Catholic political initiatives of strongly [[:es:Accidentalismo|accidentalist]] leaning, like the [[Salamanca]] gathering with [[Gil-Robles]] and [[Ángel Herrera Oria|Herrera Oria]],<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 32</ref> he stood firmly by monarchist views, also during confusion of the last months of the monarchy, at times attracting fire from the young Jaimist hot-heads.<ref>''El Cruzado Español'' 09.05.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029005384&page=5 here]</ref>
==On the rise again (1931-1934)== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11543, Madrid, Ausrufung der Zweiten Spanischen Republik.jpg|thumb|left|[[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] declared, 1931]] From his Calle de Velázquez apartment Larramendi watched revolutionary masses ruling the streets of Madrid during declaration of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] in April 1931 and soon afterwards the smoke of burning churches during [[Burning of convents in Spain (1931)|Quema de Conventos]] in May.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 32</ref> Amongst bewilderment of the Right he decided to defend the monarchist cause standing in the [[Spanish general election, 1931|forthcoming Cortes elections]] as a Jaimist candidate in Madrid. His campaign confronted the anti-clerical and anti-religious tide head on: Larramendi referred to the Church as to a truly popular structure, with priests and friars "la sangre del pueblo más humilde de España".<ref>''La Nación'' 25.06.31, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026293505&page=4 here]</ref> With his propaganda machine reduced to some 30 members of the Madrid Círculo Jaimista <ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 32, 54</ref> he gathered some 7,500 votes,<ref>''El Cruzado Español'' 25.11.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029022011&page=4 here]</ref> compared to 134,000 votes for the leading candidate and 36,000 for the last candidate elected.
During the summer Larramendi launched a new periodical, ''Criterio. Revista Semanal de Orientación Política y Literaria''. Some authors claim he was one of key people behind it,<ref>with his Manuel Palacios Olmedo, Larramendi 2000, p. 32</ref> others name him manager of the weekly, which represented "most combative Carlism".<ref>Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''1868 en la memoria carlista de 1931: dos revoluciones anticlericales y un paralelo'', [in:] ''Hispania Sacra'', 59/119 (2007), p. 346</ref> In late 1931 and early 1932 ''Criterio'' was enthusiastically supporting unification of three Traditionalist branches in [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]], though it remained a private enterprise.<ref>Moral Roncal 2007, p. 346</ref> It attracted a few known names like Pradera, [[:es:José María Pemán|Pemán]] and [[:es:José María Albiñana|Albiñana]],<ref>and Fabio, a columnist of ''El Siglo Futuro'', Larramendi 2000, p. 54</ref> but in August closed due to financial problems.<ref>having published 45 issues, Larramendi 2000, p. 32</ref> Larramendi engaged also in Traditionalist propaganda meetings, at times featured among the party pundits.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 54</ref> In late 1932 and across 1933 his activity became intense and there was hardly a month without a press note on his public harangues;<ref>compare ''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.01.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000505950&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 09.01.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000506182&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 06.03.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000508318&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 26.03.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000509170&page=2 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 08.04.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000509515&page=2 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.05.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000510451&page=1 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 24.05.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000511229&page=1 here]</ref> in June 1933 he defended in court generals accused of taking part in [[Sanjurjada]].<ref>''La Libertad'' 20.06.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003066311&page=5 here]</ref> [[File:Don Alfonso Carlos y el marqués de Villores.png|thumb|160px|Alfonso Carlos (middle)]] Though recognized in the movement as one its former leader and one of most experienced militants, during the early 1930s he did not count among top Carlist executive.<ref>in early 1932, shortly following re-unification of Carlism, he was not listed among leaders of national, regional or provincial ruling bodies, see Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''La cuestión religiosa en la Segunda República española. Iglesia y carlismo'', Madrid, 2009, {{ISBN|9788497429054}}, pp. 78-79</ref> His relations with the new party leader Rodezno have always been ambiguous; in the 1930s they were aggravated by differences on policy versus the Alfonsists; unlike Rodezno, Larramendi was as usual vehemently opposed to compromising intransigent Carlist stand<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 56</ref> and averse to entering [[:es:Renovación Española|Bloque Nacional]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 55</ref> He claimed that an alliance would turn 100 years of Carlist history, including 80,000 men who [[Carlist Wars|gave lives for their king]], into a comedy;<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 56</ref> moreover, such an ambiguous coalition would merely weaken the only force capable of confronting the revolution, namely Traditionalism.<ref>"la política de derechas no es más que un equivoco, con el cual, acqui en España, se rompe la unión tradicional de los católicos y se da una puñalada trapera al único frente opuesto a la Revolución, que es el Tradicionalismo", quoted after Larramendi 2000, p. 58</ref>
During gear-up to the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 electoral campaig]]n he was overruled by Rodezno, who pushed for a joint far-Right alliance. Larramendi decided to comply and [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|agreed to stand]] as a sole Traditionalist candidate on a joint "Coalición antimarxista" list in Madrid.<ref>''La Epoca'' 27.10.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001122688&page=1 here]</ref> The campaign in general was a triumph of the Right, but in the urban Madrid constituency [[PSOE]] retained its dominant position and Larramendi, though attracted 130,000 votes,<ref>''La Nación'' 05.12.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026323187&page=3 here]</ref> failed again. Despite the defeat suffered, he continued with intense propaganda activity, which in the mid-1930 became nothing less than hectic. There were periods when hardly a week passed by without his public appearance noted in the press,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 29.04.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000540562&page=11 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 04.05.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000541106&page=26 here], ''La Epoca'' 09.05.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001158136&page=4 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.05.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000542068&page=10 here], ''El Siglo Futuro'' 24.05.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000543459&page=19 here]</ref> the Traditionalist one hailing him as "elocuente orador".<ref>his son recalls Larramendi as great speaker, both during public meetings and in court, Larramendi 2000, p. 27, though he is characterised as appealing to logic rather than to emotions, Ferrer 1960, p. 122</ref>
==Back in the executive (1934-1937)== [[File:ULL.98.42.5.11.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Larramendi, mid-1930s]] In 1934 Rodezno was replaced as the Carlist leader by [[Manuel Fal Conde]]; the new setting suited Larramendi more, and he soon started to assume high positions within the party structures. In 1934 he was appointed to Consejo de Cultura,<ref>Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, p. 163, Ferrer 1960, p. 44</ref> a decorative body entrusted with disseminating Traditionalist thought. More important was his 1935 nomination to Consejo de Comunión Tradicionalista, set up as a collective executive supposed to assist Fal.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 57, Vallverdú i Martí 2008, p. 263, Ferrer 1958, p. 119, Ferrer 1960, p. 66, Canal 2000, p. 317</ref> Fully aligned with the leader, Larramendi went on lambasting any conservative compromise and kept voicing against new far-Right coalitions.<ref>see e.g. his rectification letters to press, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 03.02.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000574876&page=7 here], also Vallverdú i Martí 2008, p. 185, Canal 2000, p. 317</ref>
A penchant for accord with the Alfonsinos, demonstrated by some Carlists, stemmed from a looming dynastical crisis; the claimant [[Infante Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Don Alfonso Carlos]] was an octogenarian and there was no clear successor in sight. Larramendi was leaning towards the deposed Portuguese [[House of Braganza|Braganza]] family, pointing to [[Duarte Nuno, Duke of Braganza|Duarte Nuño]] as to a potential Carlist successor.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 56, Ferrer 1958, p. 113, Canal 2000, p. 306</ref> However, later he got converted to a regentialist solution. In early 1936 it was Larramendi, considered totally loyal and an excellent lawyer, who edited the royal decree of Alfonso Carlos; it nominated [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]] as the future Carlist regent.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 27, 57</ref> As authority he wrote prologue to ''Historia critica del tradicionalismo español'' of [[:es:Benedicto Torralba de Damas|Benedicio Torralba de Damas]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 21.03.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000579712&page=9 here]</ref> His vital role was reflected in the [[Spanish general election, 1936|1936 electoral campaign]], when together with Fal he negotiated a failed deal with Gil-Robles.<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2008, p. 287</ref> For unclear reasons he ran in [[Girona|Gerona]];<ref>on the Frente Catalán de Orden list</ref> his name sounded strange among Catalan candidates<ref>Vallverdú i Martí 2008, p. 289</ref> though it was [[Popular Front (Spain)|Frente Popular]] triumph which contributed to his next electoral failure.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 57, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 19.02.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000575016&page=13 here]; he gained 39,400 votes compared to 64,000 of the last frentepopulista candidate, ''La Vanguardia'' 18.02.36, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1936/02/06/pagina-13/33130915/pdf.html here]</ref> Last but not least, as an abogado he kept defending Carlists before the Republican courts.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.04.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000582256&page=18 here]</ref>
It is not clear whether Larramendi was aware of Carlist gear-up to the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|1936 coup]]. In early July with half of his children he moved to the usual family summer location in San Sebastián; his wife and remaining children joined him on July 14. When learning about the rising in [[Spanish Morocco|Morocco]] he noted „todo estaba perdido”, probably reflecting his mistrust towards the military.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 82</ref> Since in [[Gipuzkoa]] the insurgency failed, as a safety measure he moved to a nearby hotel,<ref>his 1905 defence of an Anarchist terrorist might have saved Larramendi’s life in 1936; one the San Sebastián Anarchist leaders was his neighbor and remained perfectly aware of his whereabouts, but failed to denounce him, Larramendi 2000, p. 29</ref> but on July 20 left the city and made it on foot to Navarre, already controlled by the Carlists.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 82</ref> In September, together with the victorious [[Requeté]], he returned to San Sebastián and commenced editing a new Carlist periodical, ''La Voz de España'';<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 34, 58</ref> he is also noted as helping some [[Partido Nacionalista Vasco|PNV]] activists to flee.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 34, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis], Valencia 2009, p. 93</ref> [[File:El gran visir de Marruecos, Sidi Mohamed el Llemagni, en San Sebastián (3 de 4) - Fondo Car-Kutxa Fototeka.jpg|thumb|Carlists in Donostia, 1937]] Larramendi did not enter any of the wartime Carlist ruling bodies,<ref>his not listed when discussing personal appointments in Junta Nacional Carlista de Guerra and its commissions, see Ricardo Ollaquindia, ''La Oficina de Prensa y Propaganda Carlista de Pamplona al comienzo de la guerra de 1936'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 56 (1995), pp. 499-505</ref> though he remained among close collaborators of Don Javier.<ref>among top Carlist leaders in October 1936 he travelled to Vienna to attend the funeral of Don Alfonso Carlos, Julio Aróstegui, ''Combatientes Requetés en la Guerra Civil Española (1936–1939)'', Madrid 2013, {{ISBN|9788499709758}}, p. 114</ref> Already in late 1936 he voiced against [[Falange Española de las JONS|Falangist]] drive for power;<ref>in December 1936 Larramendi wrote vaguely, though according to the present-day scholar referring to the Falangists, that "nadie tiene el derecho a descubrir ni a inventar España", Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 52</ref> when unification within a state party became a burning issue in early 1937 he tended to skepticism. He was present during a meeting of Carlist executive in [[Insua]], but there is little data on his stance.<ref>he is not listed in most detailed study on pre-unification discussions among the Carlists, see Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|9788487863523}}, pp. 241-301</ref> It seems that like most Traditionalist leaders he was disoriented; the only information available is that he insisted on clear war objectives.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 30</ref> The Insua meeting was his last appearance amongst the party leaders before the [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|Unification Decree]] was announced.
==Reclusive and patriarch (after 1937)== [[File:Desfile de tropas por las calles de San Sebastián (8 de 20) - Fondo Car-Kutxa Fototeka.jpg|thumb|left|Carlists on Francoist parade, 1940s]] Larramendi refused to join [[Francoist]] structures and criticized those who did; he verbally assaulted [[Julio Muñoz Aguilar]], co-editor from ''La Voz de España'', for an article supporting [[Francisco Franco|Franco]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 31, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 155</ref> In 1937 he closed himself for a month in a San Sebastián hotel and wrote ''El sistema tradicional''. The work was an orthodox lecture of political Traditionalism, stemming from assumption that traditionalist system does not need to be implemented: it exists as a natural phenomenon. It is not clear whether Larramendi hoped to get the work published; it was not possible before 1952, when it went to print as ''Cristiandad, Tradición y Realeza''.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 58</ref> In 1938 he agreed that two of his sons, aged 17 and 16, enlist to Requeté.<ref>Pablo Larraz Andía, Víctor Sierra-Sesumaga (eds.), ''Requetés. De las trincheras al olvidio'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788499700465}}, p. 323</ref>
In 1939 Larramendi returned to Madrid, still in touch with Don Javier. In 1940 the Alfonsist heir, [[Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona|Don Juan]], addressed the regent with a letter, seeking dynastic concord; Larramendi made sure the response was as harsh and uncompromising as possible.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 59</ref> He remained a central figure among Madrid Traditionalists<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 203</ref> and supplied party youth bulletins, issued by semi-clandestine AET, with his articles.<ref>though by some young Madrid Carlists he was considered an old-time intellectual out of touch with current reality, Josep Miralles Climent, ''Estudiantes y obreros carlistas durante la dictadura franquista. La AET, el MOT y la FOS'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|9788495735331}}, p. 35</ref> Though falling short of openly anti-Francoist language, they constituted a call for loyalty to Carlism, during its history "exonerado, proscrito, confiscado en prisiones, fusilado, asesinado, perseguido, traicionado, calumniado, silenciado, y vendido durante más de un siglo, dado por muerte mil veces", but remaining "tradición inmarcesible de la España eterna".<ref>quoted after Larramendi 2000, p. 61</ref> He took part in public Carlist events, tolerated by the regime, e.g. the annual Fiesta de los Mártires de la Tradición<ref>''Pensamiento Alaves'' 09.03.40, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1000033876&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> or funerals of Carlist leaders.<ref>''Pensamiento Alaves'' 29.04.42, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=1000032739&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Don Javier 1960.jpg|thumb|160px|Don Javier, Carlist regent and king, 1936-1975]] On the practical side, Larramendi resumed his career of a lawyer. The number of his customers decreased as they realized that the new political setting provided him with neither political influence<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 34</ref> nor any other benefits.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 34-35</ref> He continued serving some of the older clientele, e.g. in the 1940s fighting legal battles related to heritage and last will of a Carlist aristocrat, [[barón de Sangarren]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 34</ref>
In the late 1940s Larramendi, at that time almost 70, acquired the status of Carlist moral authority if not a movement's patriarch. He was aging quickly; in the 1950s he suffered heavily from [[arteriosclerosis]] and loss of sight, gradually turning almost blind.<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 34-35</ref> Nevertheless, he remained engaged in internal politics and counted among those who advocated termination of the regency, to be replaced with personal claim of Don Javier. In 1952 he presided over the Consejo Nacional de la Tradición meeting, discussing how it should be advanced; due to health reasons he did not attend the [[:es:XXXV Congreso Eucarístico Internacional|Eucharistic Congress in Barcelona]], where Don Javier was effectively introduced as a king.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 59</ref> In 1955 Larramendi met his monarch for the last time.<ref>in Gipúzkoan in Palacio de Murguía, Larramendi 2000, p. 59</ref> When in the mid-1950s the intransigent Carlist opposition to Franco came under fire as inefficient and counter-productive, Larramendi kept protesting a would-be rapprochement.<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Carlos Hugo frente a Juan Carlos. La solución federal para España que Franco rechazó'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|9788477682653}}, p. 70</ref> Some scholars claim that in 1956 he was nominated to a new Carlist executive, Secretariado General;<ref>Mercedes Vázquez de Prada, ''El nuevo rumbo político del carlismo hacia la colaboración con el régimen (1955-56)'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 69 (2009), p. 189</ref> this is not impossible, as at that time Larramendi was sort of a Carlist living saint;<ref>in October 1957 Ramón Massó, at that time leader of AET, wrote: "Alguíen, que vio el carlismo como una gran familia, diagnosticó nuestra fuerza y nuestra debilidad. Los lazos afectivos que nos unen nos hace personalistas, a favor o en contra. Olvidamos que nuestro único personalismo posible es el del Rey. Hace mas de treinta anos D. Luis H. de Larramendi vio el problema con perfecta exactitud. Para él, el carlismo se habia contagiado de los vicios políticos del viejo liberalismo", and went on to argue that a genuine Carlist should remain steadfast in unshaken loyalty to the dynasty, quoted after Miralles Climent 2007, p. 126. Though Massó's strategy was manipulation, aiming at ensuring unchallenged lead of Don Carlos Hugo to pursue an unorthodox socialismo autogestionario path later on, the quotation demonstrates that he considered it useful to refer to Larramendi as to a supreme moral authority</ref> however, others point rather to his son, Ignacio.<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Garasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo, 1962–1977'', Pamplona 1997; {{ISBN|9788431315641}}, p. 79, Ramón María Rodon Guinjoan, ''Invierno, primavera y otoño del carlismo (1939-1976)'' [PhD thesis Universitat Abat Oliba CEU], Barcelona 2015, pp. 209-210</ref>
==Reception and legacy== [[File:ULL.BLIGHTY.26.PLUS.6.IS.1.jpg|thumb|left|Fundacion Ignacio Larramendi logotype]] It seems that despite his longtime presence among top Carlist political strata, Larramendi generated little personal antagonism; cases of open challenge are scarce and seem to be rather circumstantial,<ref>''El Cruzado Español'' 09.05.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029005384&page=5 here]</ref> while there is evidence of respect even among the most die-hard Carlist enemies, the [[Anarchism in Spain|Anarchists]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 29</ref> Following death he was gradually falling into oblivion; the popular Madrid daily ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'' mentioned him for the first time in 1982, in a commemorative article by his grandson.<ref>''ABC'' 06.10.82, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1982/10/06/025.html here]</ref> It was only in the late 1980s that his name started to circulate widely in public discourse, all thanks to Fundación Hernando de Larramendi, set up by his son in 1986.<ref>now operating as Fundación Ignacio Larramendi, see ''La Fundación'' entry, [in:] ''Fundación Ignacio Larramendi'' service, available [http://www.larramendi.es/cms/elemento.cmd?id=estaticos/paginas/fundacion.html here]</ref> Its declared mission is to promote "caridad en las relaciones sociales" in line with the Catholic teaching, to act as independent think-tank, to study history of Carlism and to support non-commercial scientific research;<ref>see ''Objetivos'' entry, [in:] ''Fundación Ignacio Larramendi'' service, available [http://www.larramendi.es/cms/elemento.cmd?id=estaticos/paginas/objetivos_fundacionales.html here]</ref> its most visible activities are those related to dissemination of Traditionalist thought and promotion of Carlist studies. The foundation honors Larramendi’s name in editorial series, titled ''Colección Luis Hernando de Larramendi'', and in awards in history of Carlism, named Premio Internacional de Historia del Carlismo Luis Hernando de Larramendi.<ref>for regulations, see [http://www.larramendi.es/cms/fichero.cmd?id=estaticos/ficheros/2016-prem-carlismo-eng-ampliado.pdf here]</ref>
Luis Hernando de Larramendi gained no dedicated scholarly work; the closest thing to a monograph are chapters dedicated to his father by Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi in his book, ''Así se hizo MAPFRE'' (2000).<ref>Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi, ''Mi padre'', pp. 25-35, and ''Mi padre como político carlista'', pp. 45-79, [in:] Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi, ''Así se hizo MAPFRE. Mi tiempo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863875}}</ref> Though highly hagiographic, they provide the most detailed information available so far. Apart from well-known facts from his political career, the chapters offer also lots of private observations and recollections; they paint a picture of a Catholic taking [[Eucharist|communion]] almost every day,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 26</ref> a profoundly idealist person,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 25</ref> extremely sensitive to any sort of injustice<ref>especially injustice towards the weak and the poor, Larramendi 2000, p. 26; as late as 1957 he is referred to as defending children, deemed treated unjustly on the street, Larramendi 2000, p. 35</ref> and unrepentant in his political creed, but incapable of violence.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 27</ref> Though humble and unpretentious, he is also portrayed as intolerant versus foolishness; this trait is considered moral defect,<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 26</ref> though also an obstacle in Larramendi’s professional and political career. Tending to solitude, he ran his law office on his own and was getting outpaced by modern legal companies;<ref>Larramendi 2000, pp. 27, 31</ref> in terms of politics he built no personal following, relying entirely on his loyalty to the dynasty and trust in Traditionalist doctrine.<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 27</ref> [[File:Cristiandad, Tradición, Realeza.jpg|thumb|160px|''El sistema tradicional'', published as ''Cristiandad, Tradición, Realeza'']] In Carlist historiography Larramendi is treated briefly, usually when discussing his 1919-1921 leadership tenure and the 1936 decree of Don Alfonso Carlos.<ref>Canal 2000, pp. 275, 277, 278, 306, 318, 417, 421</ref> In history of political thought his written opus, ''El sistema tradicional'', went largely unnoticed and is not discussed in Spain.<ref>Jorge Novella Suarez, ''El pensamiento reaccionario español 1812-1975'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|9788497425483}}, Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''El pensamiento político de la derecha española en el siglo XX'', Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|9788430942237}}, Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Tradicionalismo'', [in:] Javier Fernández Sebastián (ed.), ''Diccionario político y social del siglo XX español'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788420687698}}, pp. 1163-1173</ref> Abroad Larramendi has been acknowledged as important, though not a first-row thinker, noted rather for his legal dynastic reading.<ref>and trivia like his beard, see Jacek Bartyzel, ''Nic bez Boga, nic wbrew tradycji'', Radzymin 2015, {{ISBN|9788360748732}}, pp. 17, 70, 105, 116-117, 134, 247-248, 306, 309, 338, 354, 367</ref> His son presented ''El sistema'' in sequence of great theoretical works, following those of [[Enrique Gil Robles|Gil Robles]], Vázquez de Mella and Pradera, and preceding those of [[Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola|Elías de Tejada]] and [[Rafael Gambra Ciudad|Gambra]]. He is portrayed as sworn Christian counter-revolutionary, concerned with justice in general and protection of the weak in particular. The enemy of democracy founded on [[universal suffrage]], he embraced the vision of Catholic monarchy, based on traditional social establishments and [[Corporatism|organic representation]].<ref>Larramendi 2000, p. 55</ref>

XXIX, Sevilla 1960 * Ignacio Hernando de Larramendi, ''Así se hizo MAPFRE. Mi tiempo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863875}} * Luis Hernando de Larramendi [y Martínez], ''Los Gambra y los Larramendi: una amistad carlista'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'' 10 (2004), pp. 171–174
